settings.text: An antifungal drug called Nizoral (ketoconazole) treats fungal infections.Skin infections like athlete's foot, jock itch, ringworm, and seborrhea (dry, flaky skin) are all treated with nizoral.Nizoral is also used to treat nail and skin yeast infections.

Nizoral comes in cream, gel, and shampoo forms. Using the shampoo will help with dandruff.

Tinea versicolor, a fungal infection that causes skin to become lighter or darker, is treated with the cream and gel.
Ergosterol is a crucial part of the membranes of fungal cells, and Nizoral works by preventing its synthesis. As a result, the fungal cell membrane is destroyed, which causes the fungus to die.

For two weeks, 2% of Nizoral cream should be applied once daily to the affected area(s) of skin. The dosage for Nizoral gel is also 2% applied once daily for two weeks to the affected area(s). One teaspoonful of Nizoral shampoo, or 5 mL, should be applied to wet hair and scalp and left on for three to five minutes before being washed off.

Apply Nizoral as soon as you remember if you skip a dose. Skip the missed dose and resume your regular dosing schedule if your next dose is almost due. Never use two doses at once.

Within two hours of topical application of Nizoral cream or gel, skin concentrations of ketoconazole reach their maximum levels. After use, Nizoral shampoo is quickly absorbed, reaching its peak concentrations in 30 minutes.

The liver's cytochrome P450 enzymes metabolize ketoconazole, which has a half-life of about two hours.

Combining Nizoral with other topical antifungal medications is not advised. On skin that has been sunburned, windburned, dry, chapped, or inflamed, Nizoral cream or gel should not be applied.

Combining Nizoral shampoo with other medicated shampoos is not advised. Keep Nizoral shampoo out of your eyes. If you do accidentally get shampoo in your eyes, immediately flush them out with water and call your doctor.

Ketoconazole may make some drugs like corticosteroids, cyclosporine, and tacrolimus more concentrated in the blood. Nizoral should therefore be used with caution if you also take these drugs.

There are numerous additional topical antifungal medications available. Clotrimazole (Lotrimin), miconazole (Micatin), and terbinafine (Lamisil) are a few of the most popular. The same kinds of fungal infections that Nizoral treats are frequently treated with these drugs.

Always consult your healthcare provider before selecting an alternative medication.

The use of Nizoral has not been associated with any long-term side effects. However, after prolonged use, some people might experience negative reactions, as is the case with all medications. If you have any worries, be sure to discuss them with your healthcare provider.

settings.heading: Is miconazole more effective than clotrimazole?

settings.text: Antifungal medications come in a wide variety, but not all of them work in the same way. When treating fungus infections, miconazole typically outperforms clotrimazole. However, talking with your healthcare provider is the best way to figure out which medication is best for you.

There haven't been any reports of Nizoral overdoses. However, if you believe you or another person may have used too much of this medication, call an emergency room or a poison control center right away.

Nizoral overdose symptoms could include:

Dizziness

Drowsiness

uneasy stomach

Vomiting

settings.heading: Can I use it while pregnant or breastfeeding?

settings.text: Regarding the use of Nizoral during pregnancy or breast-feeding, there is no information available. Therefore, if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, it is best to consult your healthcare provider before using this medication.
